number of helpful: 56 of 59 people (95%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 11, 2014
												It's a 2D Worms game but with a 3D engine, unlike previous Worm games in the past ,objects you see sticking out of the terrain in a map now have physics properties, they can bounc around,crush other worms,explodes,emit poison gas or even throw water around and there's now a seperate water in the game that also has some very nice looking physics to it when it moves around, this water doesn't instant kill your worms like the regular water at the bottom of the map but instead drains 1-3 HP per turn if a worm is submerged in it and everything in it moves slower (both worms and projectiles).There's also now classes in the game, Scout,Heavy and Scientists (+ the normal worm).Heavy is the slowest but can take the most abuseScout is the fastest,has the highest jumps and can perform some crazy maneuvers while walking thru terrain buuut has the lowest HP and dies the fastestThe Scientist is pretty much a healer, each turn he heals  5hp and that's about it.However if you don't wanna play with these new classes you can just simply play the Classic mode where every worm is a regular worm like in the older games.That's pretty much it, everything else is the same, It's the Worms game we all know and love since the 90's.Only major complaint i have, there's a big lack of enviroments, all you have is Beach,Sewers,Horror and a 4th one which i can't remember the name of atm, while in older Worms games you usully had at least 6 to 10 (sometimes more) enviroments for a map to keep things abit more esteticly different each time.Bottom line, it's still Worms but with a new makeover and some new fun things added it. Totally worth picking up during a nice sale and playing a few matches with your friends either via the internet or on a single computer.

content:
Posted: April 8, 2014
												After a string of rehashes, Team17 has done a fantastic job updating the series while keeping the core gameplay the same. With a polished presentation, attractive visuals and improved level design, we finally have a Worms game that doesn't feel like it emerged from a '90s time-capsule. The series remains as polarizing as ever, but those who enjoy the zany antics of the series will dig Worms Revolution.There's no revolution in this new installment of Team 17's beloved franchise, but tons of fun and crazy gadgets. New features need a good improvement if they are meant to stick around, but single and multiplayer contents will make fans happy for a bit.Worms Revolution is as good as the franchise has ever been.

number of helpful: 25 of 25 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 5, 2015
Definitely yes. As a long term Worms fan , I waited so long for a 2D release. ( 3D version were fun too, especially Mayhem and Forts ).Fantastic game to play with a friends , be it local or online. Graphic is amazing. I love background map effects, where everything moves and feels more alive. Addition of a narrator is damn sweet too. I really like him, makes the singleplayer campaign a lot more enjoyable.Also I liked the new Worms class system ( normal worm,heavy,scientist and scout ). Each one provides a different boosts/bonuses so you can customize your team as much as you like or you preffer. Add to this Worm customization stuff like cosmetics, voice,grave or dance.There is also a in-game shop so you can buy new weapons or supplies when you run out of ammo in your match. Of course first you need to find a coins on the map.About weapons. You will find the old ones but there are few new weapons , like protection shield , ufo , flamethrower etc. and newest addition of the "Watery" weapons. Yes Worms Revolution has a water physics , that means you can shoot a water from your water pistol, call a water bomb airstrike and drown your enemies. A perfect weapon to get rid of bunkering worms. It really adds some freshness to the game.Just too bad AI is kinda meh, they still stand like a artillery and noscope you with a bazookas and grenades 24/7. Despite having a inventory full of weapons.I haven't found any premade maps? Are there none? Only random maps are available? Thats sad too.

content:
Posted: May 23, 2014
												Worms Revolution is one of the best Worms games available today.I have been playing the Worms series since 1996, starting with Worms 1 on the Sega Saturn, so I am no stranger to this series.If YOU are new to this series, or curious about the new additions, you are basically controlling a team of 1-8 worms (depending on game settings) in a battle to the death with some of the craziest weapons ever.Weapons such as the Old Lady, Holy Hand Grenade, Super Sheep, Concrete Donkey, Bazooka,etc will be used as your team fights to the death in a turn-based battle with a time limit per turn and round.You also get to use a variety of utilities to move around the map such as a Ninja Rope, Jetpack, Teleport, etc.You have the option of making your own gamestyles with extensive customization settings, and this game also offers you the ability to make your own maps and play them online.Some new features for this version from other Worms series include dynamic water, new interactive physics objects, and new weapons and utilities. Yes, the rope behaves differently, (think bungee cord) but once you get used to this change you will not want to go back to the stiff rope of past worms versions. Now let's talk about system performance. Worms Revolution as you may of noticed, wants at least a dual core processor and a good video card. I have used a Pentium 4 3.60 Ghz in the past, and I was getting very playable framrates. A slow dual core seems to run this game very well paired with a good video card.Yes, there are bugs in this game involving the new physics objects, and possibly annoying aspects relating to controls, but they are mostly minor. Voice Chat works well.There is an active community online to this day, and adding friends to your friends list who play the game can help ensure full four player games often.There is A Solo Campaign you need to play to earn coins to buy new classes of Worms. Your scores will also be recorded on Steam Leaderboards. This game has classes for your worms that helps them specialize in certain situations, such as stronger attacks from a Heavy, quicker movements with a Scout, or stronger tools with Scientists.If you like the Worms series, or if this style of gameplay sounds even slightly interesting, I highly recommend you give this a look.

number of helpful: 10 of 11 people (91%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 12, 2014
												If you like the good worms games of the past (the good 2-d ones, Armageddon, World Party, those DS ones), you'll like this too. People who have never played Worms games will find this a good place to jump in. It's the same old Worms 2-d turn based "armor" fighting game, but T17 have tried to add some new elements to a franchise which has been reusing mostly the same gameplay since the 90s, and you know what, it works. The games never felt like they needed more added, but it really had to be done to make a new worms game that felt fresh. And you know what, the new additions feel right and go along great with the classic worms gameplay. And that gameplay feels right this time. Reloaded didn't really have that right feel, but this one successfully combines new and old to make something great. The campaign even is the best that its been, still unnecessary, but entertaining. Everyone knows that the old fashioned skirmish is the best way to enjoy Worms.Overall, this game is a great way to spend a half hour in a explosive, strategic (I know, I know, but I'm a darksider), and now, very wet affair.

Posted: January 19, 2016
												I've been a big fan of Worms since Armageddon, and I was disappointed to discover that this game has almost none of the charm that I've come to love about the Worms series. This game feels like it's been given a big injection of Botox: bloated and shiny, but unnatural and excessive. The best part about Worms, in my opinion, was that you were free tomake it as fair or unfair as you wanted. The old school games had the perfect mix of control and chaos, making each game an unpredictable but fun mess. This game, with it's addition of worm "classes", needless excuses for DLC, and phoned-in humor makes it a chore to play. Gone is the zaniness and difficulty that makes me love Armageddon and World Party so much. Do yourself a favor and skip this game and go get Armageddon. You'll have a better time, trust me

content:
Posted: March 2, 2016
												I remember playing Worms at a friend's place when it had just came out, and I had a lot of fun playing versus friends locally on just one PC.Playing Worms Revolution brought back some of those memories, however I ended up playing Worms Revolution mainly as a single player game. Some people say that Worms is a multiplayer game, and you're supposed to play it with other players, but I see nothing wrong with playing Worms solely for the single player campaign. If you do, just think of Worms as a sort of puzzle game, and you will probably get a lot of enjoyment out of it. Some of the missions were frustatingly difficult thanks to the incredibly accurate AI, but that just made completing them feel that much more rewarding.I played this game at the same time as I was playing Worms Clan Wars, and in my opinion Worms Revolution is by far the superior game. You can read my review of Worms Clan Wars here. I gave that game a negative review, not because I think it is a very bad game, but because this one is, in my opinion, so much better - and quite a bit cheaper as well.Here's a few of the pros of Worms Revolution:- The narrator (which is actually funny in this game, unlike that annoying woman in Worms Clan Wars)- Plenty of challenging missions- Interesting weapons (the only weapon that I missed was the Teleportation Gun from Clan Wars)- Water physicsI can't really think of any big cons. The new worm-classes (Soldier, Scientist, Scout, Heavy) were a nice addition, although not really necessary in my opinion. It can also be a bit hard to find people online, especially if you want to play  a ranked match.Still, I definitely recommend this game.→　If you are the type of person who cares about achievements, note that there are several multiplayer achievements in this game, which can be a bit troublesome to get.

content:
Posted: February 10, 2014
												Whils this game for me has more flaws than benefits, here are the good things about Worms Revolution:New weapons, making the game even more interesting.New worm types, (although by far the best is scientist)Dynamic water, which adds a whole new concept to the game.Finally, it retains the good 2d look, but with 3d features which is great.Better physics.Better Graphics (although i dont really care about graphics)And here are the pitfalls:I'm still baffled as to why Team 17 have not made it so that you can use Antialiasing in this game on AMD graphics cards. (WTF???????).The game's 'random shooting into walls' concept that was rare in previous editions is very common now. I can work out whether the enemy worm is about to hit me using this:Grenade: Direct hitBazooka: Hit, but if a wall is in the way, it will hit the wallThe worms almost never use any other weapon.Whilst terrain editor is back (finally), it is a very simplified version of the old worms games.The ninja rope (whilst more realistic), is now almost useless for proper ninja-like stunts.It is quite expensive (although luckily i got it along with the Humble Bundle).Worm customization is not as varied as it was before. In particular, the voices of worms sound very similar, almost indistinguishable.Plus, instead of WORKING OUT how to do the puzzles and missions and thinking of tactics ON YOUR OWN, when you start the mission it SHOWS YOU HOW TO COMPLETE IT. WHY??!!!!?!??!??!?!?!!?Worms will always avoid crates.Verdict: a ok game, but many people who want a challenge would prefer older games like Worms Armageddon and Worms Open warfare 2.Rating: 5/10

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 7, 2016
Worms Revolution			* 8/10The battle Worms are back in shape... In 3d shape :)Worms Revolution Follows perfectly the classic gameplay from the canonicals Worms 2/Worms Armageddon, so you always have your worms team, side view, players actions are turn based and the purpose is always the same: annihilate the adversary's team XDOne of the most typical aspects of the game is obviously the arsenal for your worms, and together with the classic weapons from previous games there are some clever innovations involving physics, such as attracting-repelling magnets, jetpacks, sentry guns, Telekinesis and my favorites: water-based weapons!... Because worms DO drown... XDI've mentioned telekinesis because now there are various Giant items around the map you can interact with, by moving them or destroying them. You can imagine what happens by blowing up a huge bottle of water, or a stinky fish?Another good innovation is the new worm class system: beside the standard average worms you can choose 3 more classes, Heavy, Scout and Scientist, each one with their own advantages and disadvantages. Creating your own team with a setup involving a number of classes that suits your gameplay can improve your results in battle.And finally you can customize your soldiers with dumb props. There are hats, and items for every taste, and if they're not there it's simply because they must be unlocked by playing the single player missions.There's a single player campaign of course, split into simple battles and puzzles with "objectives". Nothing amazing, but at least they can improve the life of the game with some challenges.The worms AI is quite the same, they keep on using bazookas and grenades (the very basic weapons) with millimetric precision even from the very edge of the terrain. So... yes the real fun and challeng is in PvP modes, both online or local.The engine isn't the most impressive and relistic engine you can see but it does its job, and sometimes with some nice results (as with the water weapons behaviors). Sometimes the engine looks a bit demanding on resources, but I can't be sure, usually I'm too focused with my team battles XD+++PROS+++ GAMEPLAY. This chapter is based on the great Worms 2 and Armageddon, representing their best reincarnation, and it goes beyond improving past their limits, both in the weaponry, stage props, interaction and custmization. CLASSES. Honestly I didn't appreciate the class system at the beginning, but by practicing more with the game I've learnt to make good use of each class in different situations. CUSTOMIZATION. Now you can give your worms some dumb and unique look. This way becomes even more simple to distinguish your own team.---CONS--- ROPE. THEY RUINED IT!!!! No more ninja extreme missions... It works totally different and really awfully... AI. Well, the AI is quite the usual, so it kind of flattens the Single payer experience. Even though this game is almost meant to be played with friends

content:
Posted: June 19, 2014
												If you are a general fan of the Worms series, this game could possibly be of interest to you.- Super customisable. Dress your worms up, give them totems, arrange their funerals, let them speak. Design your own maps and terrain.- Online competitive modes and a large campaign which tests your skills is always appreciated.- New breeds of worms have been included, a feature that I particularly enjoyed! Your team now offers more in terms of specific roles for your Worms and requires a little more strategic organisation.- Continuous commentary throughout engages you, though personally I found this irritating, a little too 'dumbed-down' for my liking. Luckily this mainly exists through Adventure Mode, so not too bad otherwise.I can see the appeal to bring the series forward into the 3D era, unfortunately, this kills it a bit for me as a player of the original 2D side-scroller. Perhaps a little too reminiscent?In this case, the original Worms Armageddon feels to be the best, still, you can expect to get a lot of enjoyment from Worms Revolution.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 26, 2016
												This isn't a perfect game by any means but it is still a lot of fun. I personally think that Worms: Armageddon is the best of all the Worms titles, and I think that Clan Wars is better than this one, but this is still good nonetheless. In Revolution, things are a bit different because there's 4 worm classes to pick from (which are unbalanced IMO) AND there is dynamic water that can move worms and slowly do damage over time. It really adds something to the traditional Worms formula. Clan Wars and Revolution are essentially the same game, only Clan Wars has less bugs, more content, larger maps, better UI and menus, a Clan System (that sucks and nobody uses anyway), etc. The thing that Revolution has over CW is overall aesthetic appeal. I find the terrain themes/backgrounds/music of Revolution much more interesting. If you're into turn-based strategy mixed with artillery games, Worms is where it's at. All of them are good in their own way, but I would definitely recommend W:A or CW over Rev. These games go on sale all of the time... you can also often find bundle sales where you can get everything for a cheap price. One thing that I will note is that the online multiplayer is kinda dead. You can still find games but you need to go to the game's hub and forums and add people there.

content:
Posted: February 17, 2014
												One of my favorite weapons in previous Worms games, rope, is absolutely usless in this new sequel. This makes moving around terrain very difficult. Bot's aim's is perfect. They use bazooka and granate, and they make incredible shoots. When you play campaign, you have limited (25 sec) to move around and aim. While bot's are so good at sniping you that they don't need to move around. Multiple bomb bounces that bot's make is something human mind could not calculate in most cases, at all, even if you had 5 minutes of time. Or shooting straight in the air, getting bazooka rocked to fall down through 2 narrow holes that were drilled by bunker buster boomb. It's simply insane. This lead to a lot of quitting in rage on my behalf. For me fun has been taken out of this game in campaign part of game. Multiplayer is good as always. Playing with friends, there is only few games that can match this level of fun.Puzzles... some are insanely difficult.Of course when you play your custom settings where you can allow yourself more time for turn that can still be fun. Water bombs and water damage is new to me, i find it interesting. Overall, I'm not not that happy with the game. If you are player who played W.Armaggedon, consider trying demo before buying. I would not buy simply for the fact that they ruined use of rope.Positive is new type of worms, and some fun new weapons and utilities. Get to know all weapons and utilities first, then play this game. Posted: May 29, 2014
												I will try to be productive with my issues, here are a breakdown of what made me dislike this game:- The backgrounds are more detailed than the foreground, it is distracting and seems odd that the actual level is really low quality and rough looking, where the chickens in the background are blooming and softened.- The frame rate is poor, I am sure for people with good PCs it will be ok, but it should be more than OK... - The water is pointless, it serves no real point other than to add some gimicy items and weapons which just get in the way and offer very little to improve the game..- The rope physics are not as much fun as previous games, they are more realistic, but realism does not mean fun... when was the last time you saw worms with rocket launchers in real life?- The worms team mechanics are completely different and no longer allow you to customize as much as previous gamesUltimately it seems to be a step back for Worms games, all they need to do is get a 2d worms game with higher rez sprites/textures.

content:
Posted: April 15, 2016
												See this game more like Worms Evolution, good gameplay but not awesome or revolutionary. Worms Revolution delivers the core Worms feeling with a great dose of humour, further introducing you to some new elements like water physics and 2.5D graphics. To me the weapon arsenal didn't feel that satisfying, compared to Worms 3D (which is the game I have played the most) which had the Homing Pigeon and Super Cow for example. To me the lack of this kind of weaponry is a major con, together with the "meh" level design, the kind of superfluous class feature, and the thin campaign. Revolution is a game I still can recommend though since the core Worms feeling is definitely there, even better if you have good company to enjoy the game with!If you are unsure whether to get this game or not, I would personally wait for Worms W.M.D. to come out, hopefully it will be a real beast when it comes out, keep the fingers crossedIf you have some good friends to play Worms Revolution with and the new features seem like something for you definitely get this game on sale. I feel it's quite overpriced at 14,99€ which is the price right now.All in all I give Worms Revolution a 6/10 + extra points if you have some buddies to battle

content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												Review in Full (tl;dr version at the end):The classic 2D Worms formula returns in Worms Revolution with a few significant changes. The new additions to the gameplay experience include four different classes, dynamic water, and physics objects, but none of the changes radically alter the familiar Worms experience.The Worms Formula: For those who don't know, the meat of any Worms game is a turn-based strategy / shooter experience where you control a team of worms and move around a map (or utilize your worms' positions) in order to use weapons such as the explosive Sheep and the famous Holy Hand Grenade to eliminate enemy worms. All Worms games have no small measure of humor, as you'd expect upon hearing the premise, and the worms themselves contribute to the humor with their own gibberish vocalizations as they taunt enemy worms and panic if a stick of dynamite is set next to them. The weapons are of course part of the humor, and the Sheep and the Holy Hand Grenade aren't even the wackiest among them. At the core, however, the gameplay experience would make for a good time in multiplayer play even without the abundant humor.New Additions (Classes, Dynamic Water, and Physics Objects):Classes: The four classes of Worms include the basic soldier, the weaker but more nimble scout, the scientist, who provides a health bonus in turn for being weaker, and the slower but stronger and more resillient heavy.Dynamic Water: The new dynamic water is an option utilized as a stage hazard and fired by three new weapons. Any worm who is knocked into dynamic water will take steady damage over time, instead of instantly drowning upon contact with normal water. Dynamic water utilizes real-world physics, sinking to the lowest area possible given its location and trajectory.Physics Objects: Physics Objects are relatively normal objects scattered around every map. The twist, however, is that each object explodes when sufficiently damaged. In the process, they unleash fires, poison gas, or even dynamic water into the immediate vicinity.Verdict and Recommendation: The wacky action of the Worms franchise is spruced up a bit by the new enhancements. None of the features radically alter the core experience, however, meaning that those who tried another Worms game but found it to be only interesting as a novelty or altogether unappealing need not apply. Worms Revolution is as good of a starting point as any for series newcomers, though, and those who enjoyed previous installments should find plenty to like here. If you are undecided, keep in mind that Worms Revolution is first-and-foremost a multiplayer experience, and the singleplayer campaign is decent, but it presents nothing to sway your decision.tl;dr version: Worms 'Revolution' is no revolution, but the perennial Worms formula didn't need to be signficantly altered anyways.

												Forget what you've learned in the old Worms series (world party, armagedon etc.) This game has different "physics" and you will be probably mad about the ninja rope which worked awesomely in WWP and here it's totally different. But still guys, it's WORMS, one of the legendary games and it is still FUN!Cons:- ninja rope and homing missile physics- probably the smaller worms ability to slide on the surface (seems to me like they don't slide as much as in the previous worms games, but as I said that's all part of the physics thing - you can get used to it)Pros:+ new utilities related to new objects in the worms environment+ water/ability to flood worms - weapons related with that+ new classes - 4 different types of worms with different skills+ easy level editorOverall I like this game, you can get over the physics and learn how to use new weapons and worm classes for new tactics.score: 85/100

content:
Posted: August 20, 2014
												A friend bought me this game and I am glad he did. Even though I have been a gamer since the 80s, I never really played any of the earlier Worms games other than a demo for one of the earliest ones (can't remember which one). Here, I'll try to do one of those "bullet point pros-and-cons" reviews:Pros good artwork - cartoonish worm characters as well as the animated backgrounds for the various levels single player campaign with varied levels and challenges multiplayer humor - the narrator is funny in that Stanley Parable sort of way; the worms have their own attitudes based on what they say customization of your worms and your formationsCons single player campaign gets difficult and frustrating - I swear the AI cheats not much elseAbout the single player campaign difficulty--the 5th map of the Farm level is SOOOOO ridiculously hard. I have tried over and over again to complete that level and I still haven't been able to do it. Once I felt I was really close; things were going well for me and it looked like it was going to happen. Guess what happened? The game CRASHED on me! It's like the game new I was going to win and killed itself rather than let that happen. I wonder if I am ever going to finish the single player campaign. UPDATE: I did end up finally getting through that level and completing the single-player campaign.This game is a lot of fun to play, period.

Posted: July 8, 2014
HILARIOUSLY FUNNY GOOD TIMES!Worms Revolution is a great game that is sure to have friendships on edge as players battle it out with crazy weaponry such as Cluster Bombs, Moles, Super Sheep, and the infamous Holy Hand Grenade. Players can choose between single player campaign, offline skirmishes, or online games with friends so there is never a shortage of carnage.The campaign isn't very long, with around 32 missions (not including missions added from DLC) but you'll be laughing through-out the entire length of it. The AI isn't a push over either, if you're as bad as I am at least, and will definitely have you hiding in the caves if you're not careful. The narrator of the campaign is a bit...annoying to say the least, but the voices from the worms make up for it in the end.Worms Revolution brings a new style of gameplay into the mix by adding classes to the classic worms game. Each class has it's own benefits to offer and can be the deciding factor on a major victory....or a horrible loss. The four classes available are Scout, Heavy, Soldier, and Scientist. Some of the benefits the classes offer are increased movement speed, increase jump height/distance, team-wide health regeneration, etc.Physics objects are also a big game changer in Worms Revolution, adding objects that are highly volatile (more so than the common oil drum), or that contain dynamic liquid that you could use to literally wash away the competition. Unfortunately it seems that some of the classic weapons have been removed from the base game but others are offered in the available DLC.All in all the game is loads of fun and it never seems to be the same game twice. I definitely recommend this game to anything looking for some casual fun offline, or for those who wish to duke it out with their friends in an epic online war and truly test friendships.

Posted: January 12, 2015
												This review is from the perspective of one who has not played a previous game in the Worms franchise.Worms, a simple concept- Groups of worms fight to the death in enviornments ranging from simple to complex,  littered with explosive barrels, guns, toxic gas, testing tubes with eyeballs inside, and many other borderline ridiculous items.Rather simple, yes? Now add some nice physics to it, and add some items, for example perhaps..Bazookas, grenades, dynamite, flamethrowers, sentry guns, water pistols, air strikes, as well as your own grandmother. That last one is a stinker.Imagine a worm gracefully flying through the air after getting hit by dynamite, followed by said worm landing on a landmine, flying into a small pit with a sentry gun and being shot into the air moments after. Seconds later, the worm has fallen into the water and met his demise. How unfortunate.Unlikely, yes? Mostly, but not entirely. Now imagine hitting worms off of an edge with a baseball bat, or simply prodding the worm the minimum distance to make him fall to his death, an insult to injury. Throwing an angry buffalo at a group of worms as it literally explodes them 6 feet into the ground. Throwing the holy hand grenade to launch a worm into the sky, dropping dynamite from your jetpack as you fly away from your helpless foes, poisioning multiple worms from a distance to cause damage over time, and even beginning the event that put an end to the dinosaurs. Meteors, explosions, the map becomes swiss cheese. Many casualties ensue-if not becoming a mass-homocide-suicide mix that turns into a draw.Only one problem, chances are that you're only going to experience this sweet action if you've got some buddies to play the game with, so you're going to have to convince your friends to buy the game if they don't have it already. The single player in this game isn't bad but it can be rather unfair and overall is only for unlocking additional worms, which isn't 100% neccessary.So forget about the single player and just focus on the multiplayer. Get some friends and cause some explosions, because this game is a lot of fun.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												While others have maligned Revolution for straying from the 2D roots of Worms while also simultaneously somewhat sticking to the popularly disliked 3D period of the franchise (in graphics, if no longer in gameplay), I personally found it fresh enough to be a tentatively recommended experience for Worms fans (though note I also have less of a grudge against the 3D Worms games than many other people). It's far from perfect (e.g. I personally found the single-player level narration from "Don Keystone" to be repetitious and unfunny probably 80 - 90% of the time), but I felt it was still decent enough if you can pick up the game for a reasonable price (I got my copy plus DLC from the Team 17 Humble Weekly Sale, for instance).Water is perhaps the most notable new feature of Revolution, and it appropriately features prominently in the logo for the game. Now, many previous Worms games featured instant kill water at the bottom of the level, but Revolution mixes things up by additionally allowing "dynamic water" to be present on regular terrain. Dynamic water isn't immediately deadly and instead works similar to a slow-acting poison (with more traditional poison weapons and effects also present in this game and other Worms games), slowly damaging any worms that are submerged and helping to win the war of attrition against worms that are not quite killed within a single turn. That's far from the only strategic use of water though, as it can be invaluable for putting out fires, washing worms into the instant kill water, and even functioning as a "soft landing" for any worms jumping or falling from high above. I feel it takes a while to fully appreciate the utility of water, especially because it tends to be far less direct than the more classic weapons like bazookas and grenades, but ultimately I feel it was a worthwhile addition to the game and not just some gimmick.Speaking of gimmicks, I'm less sold on the need for "specialist" worms. Revolution, unlike various other Worms games, features four different types or classes of worms: the Soldier, the Heavy, the Scout, and the Scientist. The Soldier is your classic worm, all around decent at everything but not particularly great at any one thing. The Heavy is a brute, dealing the most damage (sometimes impressively so with the more powerful weapons) but suffering dramatically in terms of navigation (though repeated jumps can alleviate this somewhat). The Scout is exactly the opposite, featuring the best movement and navigation abilities but some of the worst damage output. Finally, the Scientist is a bit of an odd duck, granting a small health boost every time it's their turn and with the ability to deploy some utilities better than the other worms, but otherwise is not particularly special in terms of damage output or navigation. Perhaps the differences are more stark in high level multiplayer play, but within the single-player levels I really felt like the regular Soldiers and Heavies were the most useful. Scouts were handy whenever you needed to cross long distances quickly (such as to get an out-of-the-way but quite valuable fixed spawn weapons crate), but their damage output is so pitiful that often the enemy can negate the navigation advantage by outright killing or displacing Scouts easily. I personally almost never saw the need to use Scientists in single-player play, as their slight healing powers are far outweighed by the benefits that a Soldier or Heavy can provide in terms of damage and thinning enemy ranks.So, all in all, I found it to be a decent (albeit sometimes frustrating) game, though you might personally enjoy other Worms games more.

content:
Posted: March 7
												This is one of the best games in the "Worms" franchise that I have played.  My wife and I play this game together on PC.  It's very similar to the classic "Worms Armageddon" I played on the original Playstation back in the day, but with improved visuals and a much more user friendly menu.For those who have never played a Worms game, this would make a good first one.  In Worms you have a team of worms, and you face off against your opponents' worms in field of battle.  The last man standing wins.It's got everything you would expect from a Worms game; super sheep, banana bombs, holy hand grenades, customizeable worms, and more corny one liners than you can shake a stick at.  There are however, a few additions besides just prettier graphics.This game actually adds a few different types of worms with some special abilities of their own that make it worth while to build your own custom team instead of just picking a default one, but even if you pick a default team you won't feel like you're completely outmatched when playing with somebody who has one or two of the other worms types on their team.  The abilities are useful, but not unbalancing.This game also adds water to the levels, in addition to the water at the bottom that kills you.  There's "dynamic fluids" in each map that can be added randomly, so if you notice a small pond of water on a piece of land over your opponent's head, you can blow a hole in it with your bazooka and the fluid will actually drain through the hole and wash your opponent's worm away.The game is great for kids and adults alike.  There's no real storyline, just pure, wormy mayhem.  If you're looking for a game to play with your friends or even your kids on PC, I highly recommend this one.  It fully supports use of a controller OR a keyboard and mouse, and supports local or online multiplayer, so you have lots of options for how you play.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2012
												Just how bad can a new Worms game be? Well let's see. After spending an hour trying to rebind jump from controller button 3 to controller button 2 I had to abandon my efforts all together, even after I'd written all the linked controls down on paper to resolve the conflicts. God knows how they managed to derp it up so badly. The minimum spec listed on the Store page is woefully inaccurate. Where it recommends a dual core with a minimum Radeon HD 3000 series, my quad core 4000 series struggles severely. I'd highly recommend a current era top spec machine if you expect to able to play this. Even then, mouse smoothing is perma enabled resulting in sluggish, unresponsive mouse movement and the joypad too experiences some delay. It's probably the worst Worms title I've ever played and I've played Worms Blast! My advice, avoid this like the plague.

												Not worms Armageddon / World party, nuff said, but I'll elaborate...- Screwed up ropes (using more realistic physics)- Cut down weapons and utilities arsenal, if anything, there should be MORE added, not reduced or replaced!- Worms naming and silly accessories aside, this game have almost none existent customization, meaning: no custom flags, no custom sounds, no custom maps, no REAL custom weapons arsenal + crates and damage adjust.- You can't even name your own team.- No practice maps.- Turns are slow paced (crates take forever to drop, game progress is sluggish in-between turns)Worms for me was all about the freedom they game provided both in gameplay and adjustments.I know I'm not alone in this front, which makes me wonder if the devs ever listened to the community before creating this game?

												I bought the game "Worms Revolution" during a reduction on steam for my  3 friends and me. The game title was very popular and many friends told me playing "Worms"  with friends is a lot of fun.I like the kind of gameplay in this game and i can enjoy in graphical cartoon designs. But one big disadvantage in my opinion is the fact that you need 3 other people for playing the multiplyer completely. So it was very hard for me as example to play this game with my friends because everybody have to had time to play this game to the same time.Concluding i would say that you can have a lot of fun with this game but you need friends who have time to play with you.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2014
												This game is well...good/bad and at times a bit boring (well this is kinda what i'm like for worms now but i still love this series to DEATH!) This game is a bit more different than ur other 2D worms games. Its a 3D worms game with a 2D camera basically the new weapons were pretty well thought out! But i think its stupid that you have to pay dlc for new weapons like armageddon (which has been incredibly nerfed) bufflo of lies, e.t.c. Now if you like this game thats absoultly fine i love this game too. It's different and i find this game is a breath of fresh air for the series but i would like to see them do this with the reloaded engine. But that engine has been used to death for like 5 years starting with open warfare 1 ¬_¬ and up to battle islands lol! So this game its very nicely done i think the graphics are goregous it is very impressive looking and the worms do have animations from the 3D games mostly. The weapons are good the online is a good way to play with people like always and it has a lot of single player content just to keep that person entertained while his or her friend/s are doing something else! So i give this game abbbbout...a... 8.5 out of 10 Its a very good worms game and i think newbies also might like this but i think reloaded is a good starting point and i find the next game in the series kinda a let down i mean making ur own clans is cool and stuff but its revolution but with a few new weapons and the abilty to make clans and more single player and what i think is a way more annoying announcer than revolution! >:( i know this is a nit pic but still i didnt find the announcer in revolution that funny and this one is just worse i'm sorry to who did the female voice of this announcer but i just dont like it. Well i guess i just review 2 games XD cause i did a short review of clan wars i guess this sorta makes up for it? idk but well i guess i give clan wars a score of 7.5 its good but not amazingas revolution. i reccomend it though! same with revolution i definatly reccomend revolution and i am craving for another one of these in the future of 2015! :D just hope its not a port of clan wars except its on the xbox one and ps4 JESUS JUST AWUH WHY?! well to say one good thing about that is that the frame rate is super smooth compared to clan wars which unless you have a very good pc then it will lag quite a bit. :z well anyways A WEEK TO CHRISTMAS!!!!!1!1!11! and i'll see you guys next time! ;)

content:
Posted: October 11, 2014
												I should start off saying that I love Worms games. Armageddon was amazing, and so was the fort one that game after. I even enjoyed the first 3D game once I got used to it.I was pretty disappointed with Revolution. It suddenly felt clunky, heavy, and hard to control. The movement was no longer friendly and precise, but actually felt too "real". The 2.5D style I felt really took away from the gameplay, but for reasons I can't put my finger on, other than saying it didn't feel right.Somebody playing this as their first Worms game might enjoy it, but it isn't for me, an oldschool player. I think if something isn't broke, don't fix it, and the format of the Worms games certainly was not broke.

number of helpful: 8 of 18 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 17, 2014
												Imagine the successor to a good old Worms classic like Armageddon, or its faithful follow-on Worms World Party. Update the graphics, add a few classes, and add dynamic terrain features and water physics! Oh, but the curvy graphics make it hard to play precisely, classes feel more like a restriction than an exciting array of options, the water feels insignificant and flows like treacle, and when the terrain features aren't exploding, they just bounce around like balloons. Then, take away a bunch of the weapons and options, cut it down to 16 worms in a match, remove the ability to add custom content, simplify the missions into a glorified, tedious, unrewarding tutorial, and slow the whole thing to a snail's pace. Finally, replace the glorious ninja rope with a limp noodle.Now, compared to something like Worms Reloaded, it's fine. Unfortunately, Worms Reloaded was an abortion of a game and fails miserably in comparison to the older titles. While Revolution does add a few features to try to distract from the fact that the last solid Worms game came out in 2001, the core gameplay just isn't good enough. Here's hoping we'll someday see a modern Worms title that actually builds up from the classics, instead of trying to start again.Oh, but I nearly forgot! You get to put hats on your worms!10/10 Best Game Ever

content:
Posted: October 10, 2014
												This game reels you in with the usual addictive strategy gameplay that we've come to expect from Worms games, but soon enough, I guarantee it will have you howling with frustration and rage, bitterly cursing the day you bought it. The single player campaign is easy enough to play at first, but it quickly turns one-sided. The AI worms are unforgiving, and can always pull off logic-defying, perfect shots that a human player could never hope to calculate. Oh sure, they may occasionally miss a shot, but it's all part of their endgame. You will lose. It doesn't help that the odds are firmly stacked against you at all times - your worms are often placed in the worst possible locations on the map, and the AI team always has more worms than you, often more than double. The Spooky levels are where it really becomes next to impossible. Looking for respite, I turned to the puzzles, but sorry, no rest there! The majority of the puzzles (involving using only the tools available to kill certain worms) require absolute, nitpicky precision, and I was only able to get through the later ones with online help. You will fail and fail again. I also sometimes encountered "glitches" in both modes, varying from random, mine-less explosions under my worms to weapons backfiring. The new "Worm classes" also add little to the game, and the much-touted new physics are of little consequence other than with their forced inclusion in the puzzles. I'm convinced that this game was programmed by Satan. Only buy Worms Revolution if you want your blood pressure to skyrocket and your nerves to fray. You have been warned.

content:
Posted: October 24, 2014
												So if you are thinking: "Ah, sweet childhood memories", think again. There is little of the original worms (or worms 2) to be seen in this game. The worms themselves allow for customization, which would make you believe that you have more control whereas you in fact have less. The quasi 3D enviroment is no match for the old-school bitmap like maps, making it hard to judge where you can stand/walk/jump, and distracting from the game play. The weapons still work in the same way, but the controls are all over the place and judging wind and compensating for new stuff such as water (and whether it will flow or not) is frustrating. The single player campains later on require you to get every shot and movement correct, with little to no margin for error (made more difficult by the graphics). It is not the worst worms-game I have played (worms: a space oddity for the wii takes that spot), but if you want a blast from the past, I'd suggest going for the versions released for android rather than this.

												Worms is a fun game series, this addition on the face of it seems good, but for someone like me, who is relativley new to the Worms series, it is REALLY unforgiving. If you're a beginner at this game then you will get confused about what the f*** everything does and how it works, this means that in matches with other players you will think 'Oh I have a really good opportunity here to do such and such' then you completley and utterly fail to do something due to little quirks in the gameplay that make it a lot less fun. This frustrates me and because of the minimalist tutorial, you don't get a feel for the physics, or what most of the things in the game do. On that basis I do not recommend buying this game, though if you are a seasoned veteran of the Worms series by all means, go ahead. But if not, don't bother.

												WORMS....again,the worms are back with a whole new arsenal of OLD weapons and a few new ones. It seems like sports games, worms has to come back too once every one or two years for no  reason. Nobody asked for a sequel and maybe for a reason. Team 17's constant struggle to♥♥♥♥♥♥out a new worms game is uncanny. For me personally, worms 2 was and still is the best worms game. 2D, oldschool turn-based combat and with graphics so low EVERY computer could run it.Now Team17 has to bring us a new gimmic and thus comes the beautiful physics system and the edition of water based combat. why we do not know but playing the game i must say that i feel insulted for the amount of tutorial missions i have play before i get to the first real mission. and even then the game holds my hand as if i'm a toddler. i've played worms before game, make me at least work for my victory.But apart from this flaw the game is solid, plays nice and feels just like any other worms game. the water physics don't feel realistic but unique, giving you more ways to deal with the pink ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s. The game also has a class system, allowing you to ajust your team to make certain of your units control differently and provides you with another layer of costumization. Even though i this review maybe ♥♥♥♥♥ too much at Team17 for ANOTHER worms game, the game is still true to the franchise so i do recommend this game. If however you own another worms title from only a few years ago i would stick with that as it is mostly the same with a few more weapons and instead of a 2D game you have a 2.5D game.

Posted: June 28, 2014
Worms Revolutions is the Best Release YetIf you haven’t played Worms before, the concept is simple – Worms battle each other on 2D landscape. Players take turns launching weapons at the opposing team, blowing up Worms and destroying the landscape. There are several new gameplay elements, including physical objects, Worm Classes, great voice acting, that make this an amazing game. The classes are one of the newer features and I believe it works and if you don't like it, you can just keep your formation of Worms made up of Soldiers. Worms are separated into Soldier, Heavy, Scientist, and Scout. The Soldier is the basic Worm, well rounded and the default starting Worm. Each of the other three classes has their own drawbacks and benefits. The Heavy Worm is heavy – the jetpack doesn’t last as long and he doesn’t move as fast. He also withstands more damage and deals more damage. The Scout Worm is at the opposite end of the spectrum, quick moving and weak. The Scientist Worm provides each Worm on the team with 5 health points every time his turn comes up. I like this update, it adds new strategies and fun. The Single Player missions including both campaign play and puzzles is another area of refinement for the series. The entertaining and often hysterically funny actor, Matt Barry (The IT Crowd, The Mighty Boosh, and many other film and television credits), is your guide through these well designed missions. The first set of campaign missions includes 8 training missions, to introduce gameplay and the newer features. The landscape editor allows you to create your own landscape for play. This tool is very easy to understand, so you can have your first landscape created within minutes. Worm Revolution includes nicely rendered 2D landscapes on a 3D backdrop with various themes. Choose from three gameplay modes – single player missions with Matt Berry’s voice work, online multiplayer matches, or local versus matches against the computer or your friends. Overall, this is a great game, whether you are a fan of the series of have never played it before, with simple concepts and fun quick action that can often result in hilarious outcomes. There is tons of replay value. This is one of those games that never gets old and the newer features add to the excitement.

Posted: September 1, 2014
												Can't believe I wasted money on this asinine game.  It has a terrible control scheme in which, unlike every game ever, spacebar is attack and shift is jump.  The problem is, because they are assigned to multiple commands, when you reset one, it leaves the other commands blank and you have to re-scheme the controls using separate buttons for things like skip dialog, target, and attack, which were previously all assigned to one key.  And as to the skip dialog, you will be wanting to do that because this game has awful writing, unhelpful tutorials that teach you the obvious things in the game while leaving out how to control the actual functions, and the worst voice actor I've ever heard.  Makes my sphincter clench just imagining his voice.That's not to mention all the problems with the 3D, either, including hitbox problems, seemingly random friction coefficent (except when the computer is placing perfect shots with grenades from impossible to reach places on the map).  The physics engine they use goes to complete waste, too, because most of the maps it's still more efficient to pound away with regular attacks than to try to use the water or objects strategically.Just the worst game I've ever spent money on on Steam.  Complete garbage.  Do yourself a favor and don't buy this.  This is not the Worms you know and love.  This is a crappy cheap knockoff.

Team17 still don't know what the ♥♥♥♥ makes Worms fun and their current crew are reaching some new lows.There's a not-quite-Cave-Johnson announcer talking over EVERYTHING THEY COULD FIT IN CLIPS ON. It still has the amazingly bad "Every T17 game after 2005 must shove in loading screens constantly" issue. The game begins and forces you into a tutorial that seems useless given that no enemies attack, move, or respond to you, and there's no timer. Cutscenes constantly interrupt said tutorial, explaining nothing.To top it all off even if you were thinking "maybe it still has the old charm" the voices are all changed a bit and they've added a new soundbank while killing older ones. Want "Memes"? Too bad, everyone can make you hear it online now. It's an official scheme, not some fanmade♥♥♥♥♥♥Maybe I'll change this as I give it more time, I've only done tutorial and a puzzle so far, but jesus. Jesus christ.(Reminder: this was the one where they were going to charge you money for the level editor, which is why its banner says "Includes level editor". Also, I only own this because at the time, it was the only way to get Armageddon. Which they later recanted on for more cash. Team17 worst company, guys. Please stop funding them.)

Posted: January 13, 2014
												WORMS....again,the worms are back with a whole new arsenal of OLD weapons and a few new ones. It seems like sports games, worms has to come back too once every one or two years for no  reason. Nobody asked for a sequel and maybe for a reason. Team 17's constant struggle to♥♥♥♥♥♥out a new worms game is uncanny. For me personally, worms 2 was and still is the best worms game. 2D, oldschool turn-based combat and with graphics so low EVERY computer could run it.Now Team17 has to bring us a new gimmic and thus comes the beautiful physics system and the edition of water based combat. why we do not know but playing the game i must say that i feel insulted for the amount of tutorial missions i have play before i get to the first real mission. and even then the game holds my hand as if i'm a toddler. i've played worms before game, make me at least work for my victory.But apart from this flaw the game is solid, plays nice and feels just like any other worms game. the water physics don't feel realistic but unique, giving you more ways to deal with the pink ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s. The game also has a class system, allowing you to ajust your team to make certain of your units control differently and provides you with another layer of costumization. Even though i this review maybe ♥♥♥♥♥ too much at Team17 for ANOTHER worms game, the game is still true to the franchise so i do recommend this game. If however you own another worms title from only a few years ago i would stick with that as it is mostly the same with a few more weapons and instead of a 2D game you have a 2.5D game.

Posted: January 10, 2014
												Worms is a fun game series, this addition on the face of it seems good, but for someone like me, who is relativley new to the Worms series, it is REALLY unforgiving. If you're a beginner at this game then you will get confused about what the f*** everything does and how it works, this means that in matches with other players you will think 'Oh I have a really good opportunity here to do such and such' then you completley and utterly fail to do something due to little quirks in the gameplay that make it a lot less fun. This frustrates me and because of the minimalist tutorial, you don't get a feel for the physics, or what most of the things in the game do. On that basis I do not recommend buying this game, though if you are a seasoned veteran of the Worms series by all means, go ahead. But if not, don't bother.

Posted: October 23, 2012
												I do not recommend this game to anyone who has ever played a 'proper' worms game before. Team 17 doesn't understand that by adding newer features from the game but removing  other features that made up the core experience, they were in fact destroying what worms was. More or less every game after Worms Armageddon has been a let down. I am a fan of developers trying to add innovative elements into their games, but it should never be at the cost of what made the games fun for people in the first place. The most recent tragedy occurs with the removal of team customization because the developers decided that customization should be based off profiles. Since unlike xbox live, there can be multiple profiles active on one computer at once, this means that there can only ever be one customizable team. Lame. Another completely mind blowing error that I have seen many forum users complain about over the last few games has been and continues to be the amount of worms on a team during a match.

The only times they did miss, gave the impression that they were just humouring me, and wanted to try to balance the match more in my favour.But the multiplayer cannot be faulted.

												A lot of fun but even more fun when playing with friends.The AI has definetly improved since Worms Reloaded but it's still far from perfect.My only complaint would be that it is a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥to find online-Players, i also suspect that the private lobbys aren't as private as you think since i've managed to join some by accident.All in all a really fun game, i just really would have liked to see a more active playerbase.

Posted: December 30, 2014
												I've played other worms games in the past with my friends, it was always a lot of fun and this game does not fail as a worms game. It's crazy and funny and reminds me a lot of Worms Amargedom. The controls answer very well, the weapons viriety is great, the sound is funny and the animations are awesome.I do not recommend this game for a simple reason: it doesn't support anti-aliasing in AMD graphics card. This reason will not keep me away from this game, I'll surely play a lot more of it and I definitely recommend it if you have a Nvidia card or don't care about horrible aliasing, but I've seen lots of people upset about this and hence, cannot recommend it to everyone. And remember the game uses OpenGL, so, there's no way to use a AA injector (you can still use downsampling though).Graphics: 4/10 - The lack of AA doesn't allow me to see the game's full potential here.Sound: 7.9/10  - Although they are not outstanding quality-wise, the dialogue lines are extremely funny as so are the sound effects. The music is a little annoying, but it's a matter of taste.Gameplay: 10/10 - You can blow worms, make them drown, punch them in the face, burn them, etc, all with flawless gameplay, big weapon variety, destructible environment and guaranteed laughs.Environment: 9/10 - The environment is completely destructible, there's a nice map selection available and a map editor. The water available is also very useful and well made. The background animations also make the soldiers really look like worms, in previous worms games I always felt like they were giant mutant worms.Final result: 7.7/10 - As I stated before I cannot recommend this game to everyone due to the lack of AA in AMD cards. There are lots of people who are really engaged into the "graphics war" and if one of these people buy this game and have an AMD graphics card they'll be nothing short of frustrated. If you have a Nvidia card or just don't care for heavy aliasing this is an awesome title to get.

												This is one of the worst games ever; at least when talking about SP mode, which is sad.. this could have been a small masterpiece of a game, given the fact that the concept surely is funny, and taking into account the title's history, but they surely ruined the mood by setting up that ugly, awful and ridiculous campaign, which is mostly a waste of time. I don't know what difficulty is, because the game is so smart that it won't let you choose some pre-defined difficulty for the campaign, for some reason. Furthermore, the 4th (last) part is quite absurd..Losing about 2 hours to get one mission, pff..some of us don't have that amount of time on our hands.If you want to play this game, just ignore the campaign and do it for the sake of versus mode, maybe..

Posted: January 23, 2015
												With Worms Revolution being the first Worms game I actually sat down and played since the awesome Worms World Party, I was a bit sceptical at first because the little bit I saw from the 3D Worms Games in between didn´t really click with me. This scepsis was enforced when I was greeted with the most clunky menu design I ever had to witness ... so much clicking and so confusing at the same time. Even when you got into it, it´s still a bit of a chore, escpecially in Online Play, wchich would really benefit in a better and more clear system to get games easily going. This, however, is my only big grasp with WR since the remaining game turns out to be quite excellent. I quite enjoyed the new game mechanics as in the water and the physics objects, which give the game a really nice twist. The weapons are awesome as usual with some cool new stuff, especially in the water department. The often critisised ninja rope has been changed a lot but once you got used to it it handles just fine, only different.Also, the new worms classes, while they don´t feel that special at first, actually develop a lot of depth and strategy once you learn their uses. I also enjoyed the single player mode very much. The campaign is pretty challenging and the enemy AI has a near perfect hit rate sometimes, but this can always be overcome with the right strategies. In total with the DLCs there are over 70 missions, which is a lot and should keep busy for a while. So all in all, I´d definately recommend WR. Make the menus better, and therefore have easier access to multiplayer matches and you are nearing the perfect worms experience.

Posted: May 9, 2015
												It is a fun game for what it is especially if you have other friends to play with, however the online multiplayer is dead and nobody plays anymore. I am not sure how I feel about the simplified weapons/items from previous worms games. This game didn't get enough love from the developers in my opinion. The team customization is grossly oversimplified, only a handful of voice packs for your worms. The mouse pointer has smooth scrolling which I don't like, I preferred it when you could move the screen sharply like in Worms World Party or Armagedon.I don't get why modifying your worm roster needs to switch between two windows for selecting the worm you want to swap in and out of your team.The weapon schema customization is waaaaaaay too simplified, I thought it was perfect in Worms World Party. I liked being able to modify the frequency of each item dropping.♥♥♥♥♥♥ rope physics getting caught on terrain can be annoying. Say goodbye to WXW from classic worms.HOWEVER!! The inclusion of water does add an interesting dynamic to the strategy aspect of the game. Movable physics objects also makes the game a lot more interesting. The physics in the game overall is a step forward (except rope). If you liked previous worms games I think you will love this too, just make sure you have a friend who will play with you. Also having Matt Berry voice the narrator  is certainly a sufficient enough reason to buy the game.

Posted: August 27, 2013
												Its Worms. Love 'em or hate 'em.Sadly nothing new in this title of Worms other than 3D rendered levels and characters, and what I believe to be a very simplified version of the core game.Suffers from the same thing every other Worms title offers which is lack of real customization. I'm not interested in putting a police hat and bright purple glasses on my Scottish accented avatars... I want to choose stuff like weapon restriction / availability, ammo of each weapon, health for each worm, handicaps, damage, crate drop frequency, crate drop contents, health drop frequency and quantity of health restored, even mods like one-shot-kill pistols only mode, bazooka only mode or proxy mine only modes etc but unfortunately the functionality is just not there, you have to play it 'out of the box'. Most of the weapons are not available unless you 'unlock' them or if your lucky, find them in a crate - Gives you a constant sense you're missing out on what should be a very fun game.Playing with the AI is a painful process, there is a completely unreasonable 'thinking time' is applied every single turn the AI plays... even on occasion the AI runs out of time because it can't react quickly enough... I'm talking over 60 seconds sat there waiting and watching a worm with a (?) above its head, it is ludicrous to even think that a game tester would think this is acceptable.The level editor gives this title a little more mileage if your feeling creative.In summary, unless your under 10 years old and enjoy dressing up Worms so they look like a member of the YMCA and find the humor in the notion that worms wage a war under your very feet with bazookas and shotguns, then as an adult your going to get bored very quickly.Its not a bad game production-wise, but its lack of fresh ideas really brings it down. Its basically just another Worm: <enter generic title here> game.Fortunately I have two kids under 10 years of age who seem to love the idea of a banana that explodes into mini bananas that also explode as they play/argue this game so I've had 10 hours out of it at least :)

Posted: December 20, 2013
												Ah, The Worms Franchise- it brings back memories of going over to a friend's house only to push them only and hit their keys when you two are forced to face each other with the same keyboard in a game. Worms Revolution is a Revolution indeed. This game has crafted different styles of combat, from the more evasive to the more strategic. My friends constantly hate my scouts and scientists, seeing as they always bury deep down into an untouchable hole or barrier up and heal in the untouchable fortress of girders! I really dislike the Single Player but I feel that is because this game is simply known for it's multiplayer and it thrives heavily off of that.From BB's to HHG's This games multiplayer is flawless. A ton of different modes and hilarious outcomes every game. Watch as your friend acccidentally kills two of his own worms, as he sulks knowing he's wasted his turn. (Unless he's doing the infamous "One-Turn Worm!")This is a destructive fight to the death to outsmart and outlast your opponents, who are probably also your best friends :)I give this game an 8/10Pros:New variety due to class typesI enjoy the map editorNew weaponsCons: I really dislike the new Concrete DonkeyTruly, TwR

Posted: December 16, 2012
												BE WARNED. The physics implemented in this version of worms make many of the old projectile style weapons behave quite differently to their earlier versions.  For example, the Grenade (and Cluster Bomb) now bounce like tennis balls.  The Holy Hand Grenade is not round, it's had the pin / crucifix included as part of the model so it wobbles about and catches on things.Opponent worms will still hit you with 100% accuracy across a cluttered map with a shotgun.Zoom in when doing tricky moves in order to see the ledges your worms are perched on.The Ninja rope can't be fired from a fall.  Once your worm is freefalling, that's it as far as the game is concerned, even if you had lined up a Ninja Rope shot to pull you to a nice safe spot.The game is OK, but there's still a few quirks that nead dealing with.  I think T17 is adding stuff via patches anyway.

												Don't let the name of this game fool you, this game has no relation to the Revolutions of 1848, but this is still a pretty great game. It uses great graphics to show a diverse world that can be edited to the way you want it. Also this game has a amazing story line, it depicts a conflict between four families and the struggle they have to best the other sides. However, the families will occasionally form alliances with one another to help beat the other families, but after that they are all back to fighting each other to the death. This one of the few games that makes you feel like you are right as the story unfold. You are there through every death, victory, defeat, formation of alliances, and the end of an alliance.

Posted: August 27, 2014
												The Worms franchise has been a LAN party staple for all those times at 4AM when you're too tired to play Counter Strike but still too buzzed on Red Bull to sleep. While some may criticize Revolution for being 3D-for-the-sake-of-3D, none of the charm that made the original Worms games entertaining has been lost in the translation. Mechanically, the game plays the same as the originals which is simultaneously a boon (solid controls) and a bust (pressing the wrong button and jumping instead of activating a weapon or vice-versa)If you're new to Worms the intro serves as a decent tutorial to get you into the game although the learning curve is pretty steep when it throws you directly into matches against bots.Overall, unless you're a Worms fan it's not a must buy but it's still a good one.

Posted: September 1, 2014
												Can't believe I wasted money on this asinine game.  It has a terrible control scheme in which, unlike every game ever, spacebar is attack and shift is jump.  The problem is, because they are assigned to multiple commands, when you reset one, it leaves the other commands blank and you have to re-scheme the controls using separate buttons for things like skip dialog, target, and attack, which were previously all assigned to one key.  And as to the skip dialog, you will be wanting to do that because this game has awful writing, unhelpful tutorials that teach you the obvious things in the game while leaving out how to control the actual functions, and the worst voice actor I've ever heard.  Makes my sphincter clench just imagining his voice.That's not to mention all the problems with the 3D, either, including hitbox problems, seemingly random friction coefficent (except when the computer is placing perfect shots with grenades from impossible to reach places on the map).  The physics engine they use goes to complete waste, too, because most of the maps it's still more efficient to pound away with regular attacks than to try to use the water or objects strategically.Just the worst game I've ever spent money on on Steam.  Complete garbage.  Do yourself a favor and don't buy this.  This is not the Worms you know and love.  This is a crappy cheap knockoff.

Posted: December 3, 2014
												As with all Worms games, this one can get really frustrating when you are trying to figure out the best strategy to dominate a level and 'go for gold'. Seriously, I played some of the campaign levels 20+ times before I got them. Despite this hereditary feature, this one is pretty good amongst the rest of the series. Perhaps the most interesting additions are the Worm Classes; Soldier, Scout, Heavy and Scientist. Each different Worm Class offers different benefits and carries different weaknesses (i.e. reduced movement speed & agility or lower damage resistance) which makes for more challenging gameplay than a homogenous team (as you might get in Worms Reloaded). That, and the VO acting being done by Matt Berry (Douglas Reynholm from The I.T. Crowd) adds a ridiculous charm to the game. Much happier with this than Worms Clan Wars! ****

Posted: June 23, 2014
												Simply put, it's the Worms you know and love.  You control worms using over the top weapons to kill other worms.  For example, grenades have a timer and can be bounced to its target, Bazooka can't.  There are some nice single player missions that go from easy to throwing-things-at-the-wall-AI cheating and never misses hard.  The true value of this game is playing with other people.  It's kind of like a board game that way, the board chatter, banter, and trash talk make the game infinitely more enjoyable.  Also like a board game, if you have people to play with and you like the concept, buy it for yourself and get friends to do the same.  Solo play?  Maybe if you get it very cheap.

Posted: January 23, 2015
												With Worms Revolution being the first Worms game I actually sat down and played since the awesome Worms World Party, I was a bit sceptical at first because the little bit I saw from the 3D Worms Games in between didn´t really click with me. This scepsis was enforced when I was greeted with the most clunky menu design I ever had to witness ... so much clicking and so confusing at the same time. Even when you got into it, it´s still a bit of a chore, escpecially in Online Play, wchich would really benefit in a better and more clear system to get games easily going. This, however, is my only big grasp with WR since the remaining game turns out to be quite excellent. I quite enjoyed the new game mechanics as in the water and the physics objects, which give the game a really nice twist. The weapons are awesome as usual with some cool new stuff, especially in the water department. The often critisised ninja rope has been changed a lot but once you got used to it it handles just fine, only different.Also, the new worms classes, while they don´t feel that special at first, actually develop a lot of depth and strategy once you learn their uses. I also enjoyed the single player mode very much. The campaign is pretty challenging and the enemy AI has a near perfect hit rate sometimes, but this can always be overcome with the right strategies. In total with the DLCs there are over 70 missions, which is a lot and should keep busy for a while. So all in all, I´d definately recommend WR. Make the menus better, and therefore have easier access to multiplayer matches and you are nearing the perfect worms experience.

												Its Worms. Love 'em or hate 'em.Sadly nothing new in this title of Worms other than 3D rendered levels and characters, and what I believe to be a very simplified version of the core game.Suffers from the same thing every other Worms title offers which is lack of real customization. I'm not interested in putting a police hat and bright purple glasses on my Scottish accented avatars... I want to choose stuff like weapon restriction / availability, ammo of each weapon, health for each worm, handicaps, damage, crate drop frequency, crate drop contents, health drop frequency and quantity of health restored, even mods like one-shot-kill pistols only mode, bazooka only mode or proxy mine only modes etc but unfortunately the functionality is just not there, you have to play it 'out of the box'. Most of the weapons are not available unless you 'unlock' them or if your lucky, find them in a crate - Gives you a constant sense you're missing out on what should be a very fun game.Playing with the AI is a painful process, there is a completely unreasonable 'thinking time' is applied every single turn the AI plays... even on occasion the AI runs out of time because it can't react quickly enough... I'm talking over 60 seconds sat there waiting and watching a worm with a (?) above its head, it is ludicrous to even think that a game tester would think this is acceptable.The level editor gives this title a little more mileage if your feeling creative.In summary, unless your under 10 years old and enjoy dressing up Worms so they look like a member of the YMCA and find the humor in the notion that worms wage a war under your very feet with bazookas and shotguns, then as an adult your going to get bored very quickly.Its not a bad game production-wise, but its lack of fresh ideas really brings it down. Its basically just another Worm: <enter generic title here> game.Fortunately I have two kids under 10 years of age who seem to love the idea of a banana that explodes into mini bananas that also explode as they play/argue this game so I've had 10 hours out of it at least :)

Posted: January 13, 2014
												WORMS....again,the worms are back with a whole new arsenal of OLD weapons and a few new ones. It seems like sports games, worms has to come back too once every one or two years for no  reason. Nobody asked for a sequel and maybe for a reason. Team 17's constant struggle to♥♥♥♥♥♥out a new worms game is uncanny. For me personally, worms 2 was and still is the best worms game. 2D, oldschool turn-based combat and with graphics so low EVERY computer could run it.Now Team17 has to bring us a new gimmic and thus comes the beautiful physics system and the edition of water based combat. why we do not know but playing the game i must say that i feel insulted for the amount of tutorial missions i have play before i get to the first real mission. and even then the game holds my hand as if i'm a toddler. i've played worms before game, make me at least work for my victory.But apart from this flaw the game is solid, plays nice and feels just like any other worms game. the water physics don't feel realistic but unique, giving you more ways to deal with the pink ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s. The game also has a class system, allowing you to ajust your team to make certain of your units control differently and provides you with another layer of costumization. Even though i this review maybe ♥♥♥♥♥ too much at Team17 for ANOTHER worms game, the game is still true to the franchise so i do recommend this game. If however you own another worms title from only a few years ago i would stick with that as it is mostly the same with a few more weapons and instead of a 2D game you have a 2.5D game.

Posted: September 26, 2014
												The multiplayer in this game is some of the best out there. Customizable game modes, a map creator, and lots of items.However, this game isn't perfect. For one thing, the platforming is terrible. If you fall and take damage, costing you your turn, half the time the controls are to blame.Then there's the single player campaign. The AI is the very definition of perfection, and is some of the most unfair AI I've ever seen, and I've played a lot of Mario Kart in my time. You could be on a tiny floating chunk of land just big enough to stand on and an AI worm can throw a grenade from across the map, ricochet it off walls and celings and get it to land perfectly on that worm's head without bouncing off. Not only are they unfair, but as you progress, they start to outnumber you more and more. I've gotten to the point where I've started with only 4 worms and the AI has 10. Unless you're the kind of person who enjoys games like Dark Souls, where the challenge is based on how unfair the AI is, I wouldn't touch the singleplayer with a 10 foot pole.That aside though, this game is clearly meant to be played with friends anyways, and it's definitly worth the buy just for the multiplayer.
